author: Claire Heaney
title: Melbourne family eyeing globe with men’s grooming range, Black Leopard
text:
AFTER selling his software company, Peter Collins was eager to develop a family business with his adult children.
They sat down, discussed some concepts and “finally came up with the idea of a men’s skincare range”, Mr Collins says.
Two years on, the Armadale-based business, Black Leopard, is poised to open its first shop and it has had interest from prospective customers around the globe.
With wife Robyn a trained beautician, the family of three boys and a girl had been educated about the importance of skincare from a young age, Mr Collins says.
Reflecting on their early work setting up the brand, Mr Collins says they sought the input of cosmetic chemist Richard Gonano to devise an earthy citrus signature fragrance.
Once they came up with the products, they sourced a local manufacturer and packaging.
The three sons have been involved in developing the business, juggling it with their day jobs: Murdoch, 25, has sales and marketing experience, Tyson, 27, works in radio and models and Lachlan, 30, is in sports management.
“It is great for me to be involved in a business with them. I am in my 60s and they are in their 20s and 30s and it is great to have something we are united to do,” Mr Collins says.
He says Murdoch is essentially employed full time in the business with plans to open a shopfront in South Yarra this month. They have weekly meetings and Tyson and Lachlan contribute about half a day a week.
“I would love to see them, in a year, all working full time in the business.”
The family attended cosmetic showcase Cosmoprof in Italy late last year and Mr Collins says they believe there is a gap in the market for men’s skincare products.
He says representatives from 30 to 40 countries have expressed their interest.
They’ve sent samples to the United Arab Emirates, India and Ukraine. But, Mr Collins, says they felt they needed to consolidate the local operation before casting the net.
They have set up an online presence, working hard to tap into social media and are talking to some big retailers about stocking Black Leopard.
Mr Collins says they are working their way through a five-year business plan. The range has 13 face, hair and body products, priced from $15 to $60.
